caption: A solid base color can be specified directly on the node.

caption: An image is used as the glTF base color.

contextAfter: An image is used as the glTF base color.

contextBefore: From an Ambiant Occlusion node connected to the Base Color input. (The AO socket is not used in glTF, but the color output can be used as a base color.)

caption: A metallic/roughness image connected in a manner consistent with the glTF standard, allowing it to be used verbatim inside an exported glTF file.

contextAfter: A metallic/roughness image connected in a manner consistent with the glTF standard, allowing it to be used verbatim inside an exported glTF file.

caption: A pre-baked ambient occlusion map, connected to a node that doesn’t render but will export to glTF.

caption: This combination of nodes mimics the way glTF packs occlusion, roughness, and metallic values into a single image.

contextAfter: This combination of nodes mimics the way glTF packs occlusion, roughness, and metallic values into a single image.

caption: A normal map image connected such that the exporter will find it and copy it to the glTF file.

contextAfter: A normal map image connected such that the exporter will find it and copy it to the glTF file.

caption: This arrangement is supported for backwards compatibility. It is simpler to use the Principled BSDF node directly.

caption: Basic Face Landmarks.

caption: Eyes-Nose Landmarks.

caption: Jaw-Ear Bone Positions.
contextBefore: Keeping aligned the mid bones in “brow”, “brow.b”, “lid.t”, “lid.t” and cheek will give better results after rig generation.

caption: Lips Merge Point.
contextBefore: Try to place “ear.L” bone covering the part of the ear attached to the mandible (lower jaw). Do the same with temple bone trying to cover the part you don’t want to move with the jaw, this way you will also determine the jaw pivot position.

caption: Face Stretcher Bones.
contextBefore: While moving the face bones it is necessary to preserve merge points, i.e. whenever heads or tails of two or more bones overlap at the same point, they should still do so after repositioning. Tearing a merge point apart may result in mul...

caption: Eyes Pivot Position.
contextBefore: Position the eye bones in the eye pivot point facing right toward the face on the Y axis. The length of the eye bones should correspond to the radius of the eye.

caption: Mouth and Teeth Positions.
contextBefore: Finally position the teeth bones on your teeth geometry and the tongue bone chain as described in the figure.

caption: Torso Landmarks.
contextBefore: Head, chest and pelvis are rigid zones, so they require less bones. Having a good edge loop placement around zone boundaries on your model will help in having correct deformation after armature binding.

caption: Torso Bones Positioning.
contextBefore: Even if the pelvis bones will not appear in the final rig as controls, they will contribute to deformation.

caption: Arm Bones Positioning.
contextBefore: While placing the arm bones try to start having a straight line that goes from the shoulder to the hand in both front and top view. After this is done just add a slight bend to the elbow. This can be easily done by going in the top view,...

caption: Leg Bones Positioning.
contextBefore: For the leg you can follow a similar process. Start by aligning the leg bones creating a straight line from the hips to the ankle, then place the foot and the toe accordingly. Remember to add a slight bend to the knee. This can be easily...

caption: Knuckles Edge Loops and Cursor Snapping.

contextAfter: Knuckles Edge Loops and Cursor Snapping.

caption: Palm Alignment.
contextBefore: When the fingers are in place proceed placing the palm bones.

headingPath: Generated Rig Features / Face / Basic Concepts
contextBefore: This describes the new-style modular face produced by the Upgrade Face operator button.
contextAfter: The foundation of the Rigify face is a network of Bendy Bone chains with controls placed at every bone end. These controls affect all bones that meet at that specific point.

contextBefore: Certain areas of the face, like eyes or mouth, have additional specialized controllers that apply custom behavior on top of the chains and their controllers within the relevant area.

caption: When enabling Follow Curve, the cone is offset along the curve point’s tangent.
contextBefore: After adding the constraint, the cone is offset along the Curve’s local Y axis.
contextAfter: When enabling Follow Curve, the cone is offset along the curve point’s tangent.

caption: Follow Path constraint.
contextBefore: To have the owner perfectly positioned and aligned on the Curve, ensure its world position and rotation are both zero. This can be done by pressing Alt - G and Alt - R respectively.

caption: Geometry Attribute constraint.
contextBefore: The Geometry Attribute constraint transforms an object or bone according to a target object’s sampled geometry attribute data. This allows motion and deformation to be driven directly by procedural geometry outputs, such as positions or...

caption: Pivot constraint.
contextBefore: The Pivot constraint makes an object or bone rotate around a point other than its origin . This can be a point that’s relative to the same or another object/bone, or a point that’s fixed in space.

caption: Shrinkwrap constraint.
contextBefore: Like other constraints, the Shrinkwrap constraint ignores the geometry of its owner object and purely works with its origin . This means that, if the origin is at the object’s center, the object will clip into the target mesh instead of...

caption: Clamp To constraint.
contextBefore: The Follow Path Constraint can not just position an object/bone on a Curve, but also orient it along the Curve’s direction.

caption: Damped Track constraint.
contextBefore: The word “damped” means that the constraint uses a pure swing rotation to minimize rolling around the tracking axis. This is in contrast to the Track To Constraint which applies an “Up” axis in addition to the tracking.

caption: Inverse Kinematics constraint.
contextBefore: The IK constraints are special in that they modify multiple bones. For this reason, they ignore their position in the stack and always run after all other constraints on the affected bones. To apply constraints after IK, it is necessary...

caption: Locked Track constraint.
contextBefore: This constraint can be used in combination with other Track constraints. For example, first add a Damped Track constraint to orient the X/Y plane based on one target, then add a Locked Track constraint to rotate within that plane towards...

caption: Spline IK constraint.
contextBefore: The IK constraints are special in that they modify multiple bones. For this reason, they ignore their position in the stack and always run after all other constraints on the affected bones. To apply constraints after IK, it is necessary...

caption: Stretch To constraint.
contextBefore: The constraint can also perform “volume preservation,” making the owner thinner when the target moves away and thicker when it comes closer. This is useful for stretching and squashing of stylized characters, for example. However, becaus...

caption: Track To constraint.
contextBefore: If the constraint owner is almost directly above the target, the roll around the tracking axis will become unstable. For this scenario, it’s recommended to use the Damped Track Constraint instead.

caption: Copy Location constraint.
contextBefore: This constraint has no effect on connected bones as their position is determined by their parent bone.

caption: Copy Rotation constraint.
contextBefore: The Copy Rotation constraint forces an object or bone to match the rotation of a target.

caption: Copy Scale constraint.
contextBefore: The Copy Scale constraint forces an object or bone to match the scale of a target.

caption: Copy Transforms constraint.
contextBefore: The Copy Transforms constraint forces an object or bone to match the location, rotation, and scale of a target.

caption: If a child bone is rotated and its parent is non-uniformly scaled, it will get sheared, and so will any object that copies its transformation (middle cube). Use Remove Target Shear to fix this (right cube).
contextBefore: Removes shearing from the Target’s transformation before Mixing, ensuring it consists purely of translation, rotation, and scale.
contextAfter: If a child bone is rotated and its parent is non-uniformly scaled, it will get sheared, and so will any object that copies its transformation (middle cube). Use Remove Target Shear to fix this (right cube).

caption: No constraint.
contextBefore: Like Before Original , except the result is the transformation of the target if it were a child of the owner.

caption: With Before Original (Full) , the cone is scaled along the cube’s Y axis, causing shearing.
contextBefore: No constraint.
contextAfter: With Before Original (Full) , the cone is scaled along the cube’s Y axis, causing shearing.

caption: With Before Original (Aligned) , the cone is scaled along its own Y axis, preventing shearing.
contextBefore: With Before Original (Full) , the cone is scaled along the cube’s Y axis, causing shearing.
contextAfter: With Before Original (Aligned) , the cone is scaled along its own Y axis, preventing shearing.

caption: With Before Original (Split Channels) , the cone’s location is independent of the cube’s rotation and scale.
contextBefore: With Before Original (Aligned) , the cone is scaled along its own Y axis, preventing shearing.
contextAfter: With Before Original (Split Channels) , the cone’s location is independent of the cube’s rotation and scale.

caption: Limit Distance constraint.
contextBefore: This constraint has no effect on connected bones as their position is determined by their parent bone.

caption: Limit Location constraint.
contextBefore: Floor Constraint

caption: Limit Rotation constraint.
contextBefore: This constraint doesn’t work for bones that are affected by Inverse Kinematics . Please use the Limit settings in the bone’s IK panel instead.

caption: Limit Scale constraint.
contextBefore: While it’s possible to set limits of 0 or less, these will not work correctly and should be avoided.

caption: Maintain Volume constraint.
contextBefore: The Maintain Volume constraint ensures that an object or bone keeps its original volume by automatically scaling down two axes when another axis is scaled up (and vice versa). This can be useful for stretching and squashing stylized char...

caption: Transform Cache Constraint.
contextBefore: The constraint is automatically added when importing such a file. However, it only applies to transforms (location/rotation/scale of the whole object). For animations that cause deformation, the Mesh Sequence Cache Modifier is used instead.

caption: Transformation constraint.
contextBefore: The constraint works with input and output value ranges, one for each axis. It first clamps the input value to the Map From range, then offsets and scales it to the corresponding Map To range. This lets you, say, map a Y coordinate in th...

caption: Extrapolate disabled: the output values are limited to the Map To range.

contextAfter: Extrapolate disabled: the output values are limited to the Map To range.

caption: Extrapolate enabled: the output values can extend beyond the limits.

The Sensor Noise node simulates the random noise patterns produced by digital camera sensors. This can be used to match real footage, add realism to rendered images, or stylistically mimic the imperfections of digital imaging systems.

The Vignette node darkens or fades out the edges of an image to draw attention toward the center. This effect is often used for artistic or cinematic purposes to create focus, mood, or a sense of depth.

pageTitle: RGB to BW Node - Blender 5.0 Manual

The Separate Color Node splits an image into its composite color channels. The node can output multiple Color Models depending on the Mode property.

The Set Alpha Node adds an alpha channel to an image.

headingPath: Set Alpha Node / Example / Fade To Black
caption: Fade to black.
contextBefore: To transition the audience from one scene or shot to another, a common technique is to “fade to black”. As its name implies, the scene fades to a black screen. You can also “fade to white” or whatever color you wish, but black is a good...

caption: Using Set Alpha to fade in a title.

The Sepia node applies a warm, brownish color tint to the image, emulating the look of vintage photographs or old film prints. It can be used to create nostalgic, cinematic, or stylized color grades that mimic chemical sepia toning proce...

The Split Toning node applies different color tints to the highlights and shadows of an image. This technique is widely used in photography and color grading to create mood, enhance contrast, or stylize an image by giving distinct color...

The Tune Image node provides a quick and intuitive way to enhance an image’s overall appearance by adjusting key visual parameters such as contrast, clarity, and sharpness. It is designed as a compact, all-in-one correction tool for fine...

The Vector Blur node is a fast method for simulating Motion Blur in compositing. It uses the vector speed render pass to blur the image pixels in 2D.

The Convolve node performs a 2D convolution operation on an image using a custom Image Kernel . This allows for a wide range of effects such as blurring, sharpening, and edge detection, depending on the kernel values provided.
The Denoise node is used to denoise renders from Cycles and other ray tracing renderers. This helps to significantly reduce render time by rendering with fewer samples.

caption: Render before and after denoising, with a very low number of samples as input. As more samples are used, the denoiser will be able to better preserve detail.
contextBefore: Denoised image output.
contextAfter: Render before and after denoising, with a very low number of samples as input. As more samples are used, the denoiser will be able to better preserve detail.
The Despeckle node is used to smooth areas of an image in which noise is noticeable, while leaving complex areas untouched.
Expands or shrinks a mask using a morphological operator.

contextAfter: The Glare Node enhances bright areas of an image by adding effects such as lens flares, bloom, and fog glow. It simulates the way light interacts with lenses, creating realistic or artistic highlights and reflections.

contextAfter: The Inpaint node is used to extend borders of an image into transparent or masked regions. This can be useful to solve problems like “wire removal” and holes created during chroma keying.

The Value Node is a simple node to input numerical values to other nodes in the tree.

contextAfter: The Group Input node provides access to input sockets of a node group. It acts as the entry point for data passed into the group from the outside, such as images, values, or other data types.
The Image node injects any image format that is supported by Blender .

The Image Coordinates node outputs various coordinate fields for an input image. These outputs provide information about each pixel’s location in different coordinate spaces, which can be useful for procedural texturing, compositing effe...
The Image Info node outputs spatial and transformation information about an image in the compositor.
The Mask node can be used to select a Mask data-block . This node can be used with other nodes, for example to Invert, Multiply or Mix, or used as a factor input.

Renders a View Layer and reads its Passes into the compositing node graph.
The Scene Time node outputs the current time in the scene’s animation in units of seconds or frames.
The Time Curve node generates a factor value (from 0.0 to 1.0) between the scene start and end time, using a curve mapping.

caption: Time controls from left to right: no effect, slow down, freeze, accelerate, reverse.

The Channel Key node determines background objects from foreground objects by the difference in the selected channel’s levels.
The Chroma Key node determines if a pixel is a foreground or background (and thereby should be transparent) based on its chroma values.

The Color Key node is used for chroma keying—removing parts of an image based on color. It is commonly used to remove backgrounds like green screens or blue screens from footage, creating a matte where selected colors become transparent.
The Color Spill node is used to suppress unwanted color casts—typically green or blue; caused by light reflecting from a chroma key (green or blue screen) onto the subject.

caption: Before: green border and green reflections.
contextBefore: Results with the nodes applied to an image from the Mango Open Movie .
contextAfter: Before: green border and green reflections.

caption: After: no unwanted green.
contextBefore: Before: green border and green reflections.

contextAfter: This node produces a matte that isolates foreground content by comparing it with a reference background image.
The Distance Key node determines a pixel’s alpha value based on the three-dimensional distance between the image pixel color and the key color in a 3D color space.

The Keying node is a one-stop-shop for “green screen” / “blue screen” removal. It performs both chroma keying to remove the backdrop and despill to correct color cast from the backdrop. Additionally, you can perform common operations use...

The Keying Screen node creates plates for use as a color reference for keying nodes. It generates gradients from sampled colors on motion tracking points on movie clips. It can be used to deal with uneven colors of green screens.

The Box Mask node creates an image suitable for use as a simple matte.

The Cryptomatte node uses a Cryptomatte image to create a mask for one or more objects or materials. The input matte is typically generated by Blender itself (see the Cryptomatte render pass ), but can also come from other software that...

The Cryptomatte node uses the Cryptomatte standard to efficiently create mattes for compositing. Cycles and EEVEE output the required render passes, which can then be used in the Compositor or another compositor with Cryptomatte support...

The ID Mask Node creates a mask for a particular object or material in the render. It relies on the Object Index or Material Index render pass , which is only available when rendering with Cycles.

caption: Object Pass Index.
contextBefore: The index for which to create a mask. This index can be configured for objects at Properties ‣ Object ‣ Relations ‣ Pass Index , and for materials at Properties ‣ Material ‣ Settings ‣ Pass Index .

caption: ID Mask node example.

contextAfter: The Enable Output node toggles the visibility and value of a socket for a Node Group outputs. It can be used to conditionally show or hide outputs from a node group depending on an input value or condition.

The File Output node writes one or more images to disk during rendering or compositing. Each connected input is saved to the specified directory and filename, with the frame number appended to create a sequence. For example: {Directory}/...

The Group Output node defines the final output of a node group. It determines which values are passed out of the node group to the parent node tree (or to the renderer, in the case of the Compositor).

The Viewer node is used to preview image data or value maps anywhere within a compositor node graph. It is a diagnostic tool that allows users to inspect intermediate results without affecting the final output.

contextBefore: The White Noise Texture node returns a random number based on an input Seed . The seed can be a number, a 2D vector, a 3D vector, or a 4D vector; depending on the Dimensions property. The output number ranges between zero and one.

pageTitle: White Noise Texture Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Precision issue due to signed zeros on the Z axis.
contextBefore: Taking the absolute value of the seed. In computing, zero may be positive or negative, so taking the absolute values unifies the zero into a single value.
contextAfter: Precision issue due to signed zeros on the Z axis.

The Displace Node displaces the pixel position based on an input vector.
The Flip node flips the input image horizontally, vertically, or both, based on the inputs provided.
Use this node to simulate distortions that real camera lenses produce.

The Levels Node read the input color channels and outputs analytical values. The output is one-dimensional meaning the visualization will be a uniform gray color.
The Clamp node clamps a value between a minimum and a maximum.

pageTitle: Relative To Pixel Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Relative To Pixel node converts values that are relative to the image size into values in pixel units. This is useful when working with screen-space operations that require absolute pixel values, such as blurring or positioning effec...

The Retime node controls the timing of input sequences, animations, or time-based effects by offsetting, skipping, or repeating frames. It can be used to create time remapping effects such as slow motion, fast-forward, looping, or rhythm...

The Split node combines two input images into a single output image, displaying them side by side or along a rotated split line. This is useful for comparing two versions of an image, such as before and after a color correction, composit...

The Switch View node combines the views (left and right) into a single stereo 3D output. This can be useful if for example, you need to treat the view as separate images by combining each of the views.

The Combine Cylindrical node converts cylindrical coordinates (R, Φ, Z) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Cylindrical node.
The Combine Spherical node converts spherical coordinates (R, Φ, Θ) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Spherical node.
The Combine XYZ Node combines a vector from its individual components.

caption: Linear.
contextBefore: The curve holds the value until the next keyframe, producing a stair step effect with very abrupt changes. Normally only used during the initial “blocking” stage in pose-to-pose animation workflows.

caption: Bézier.
contextBefore: The curve goes from one keyframe to the next in a straight line, which prevents abrupt changes in value but not in speed. By creating two keyframes with Linear interpolation and extrapolation , you can easily make a straight line curve t...

caption: Auto handles.
contextBefore: If you want to change an automatic handle’s position, just drag it; you don’t need to manually change its type first.

caption: Auto clamped handles.
contextBefore: Automatic handles that produce smooth curves.

caption: Vector handles.
contextBefore: Automatic handles clamped to prevent overshoots and changes in the curve direction between keyframes (S-shapes).

caption: Aligned handles.
contextBefore: Automatic handles that produce straight curve segments (like linear interpolation).

caption: Free handles.
contextBefore: Manual handles, which are however locked together to always point in opposite directions. This results in a curve that is always smooth at the control point.

contextBefore: The Graph Editor lets you edit animation curves, which determine how properties change over time.

caption: Example of a node editor.
contextBefore: Blender contains different node-based editors with different purposes, so this section only explains how to work with nodes in general. The list below shows the different types of nodes and where they’re documented.

contextBefore: All nodes in Blender are based on a similar construction. This applies to any type of node . These parts include the title, sockets, properties and more.
contextAfter: The title shows the name/type of the node; it can be overridden by changing the node’s Label . On the left side of the title is the collapse toggle which can be used to collapse the node. This can also be done with H .

caption: How a node appears when collapsed.
contextBefore: The title shows the name/type of the node; it can be overridden by changing the node’s Label . On the left side of the title is the collapse toggle which can be used to collapse the node. This can also be done with H .
contextAfter: How a node appears when collapsed.

contextBefore: Each socket is color-coded depending on what type of data it handles.

caption: An example of the controls on the Chroma Key node.
contextBefore: Many nodes have settings which can affect the way they interact with inputs and outputs. Node settings are located below the outputs and above any inputs.
contextAfter: An example of the controls on the Chroma Key node.

caption: Example of a Frame node used to organize nodes.
contextBefore: Frames are particularly useful when the setup is too large to view easily at once, or when you want to separate logical sections of a node tree without creating a reusable Node Group.
contextAfter: Example of a Frame node used to organize nodes.

contextBefore: The frame can display a custom label, useful for naming sections of your node setup.
contextAfter: Font size of the label. For example, for subordinate frames to have smaller titles.

contextBefore: To quickly add a Reroute node into an existing connection, hold Shift and RMB while sweeping across the link to add a Reroute node .
contextAfter: Input value used for unconnected sockets.

The Enable Output node toggles the visibility and value of a socket for a Node Group outputs. It can be used to conditionally show or hide outputs from a node group depending on an input value or condition.

The Combine Bundle node creates a new Bundle from multiple input values. Each input becomes an element of the bundle, identified by its socket name. Values can be accessed in other parts of the node tree using the Separate Bundle

caption: A cube and cylinder combined into a bundle, then separated again.
contextBefore: Bundles reduce the number of exposed inputs and outputs in a node group, and can contain mixed data types such as geometry, fields, values, objects, or even nested bundles.
contextAfter: A cube and cylinder combined into a bundle, then separated again.
The Join Bundle node combines multiple bundles into a single output bundle. Each connected input bundle is merged together, producing one bundle that contains all items from the inputs.
The Separate Bundle node extracts individual values from a Bundle . Each output corresponds to an element in the bundle, identified by its socket name.

caption: An empty closure zone.
contextBefore: Closures allow users to pass custom procedural logic into node groups, making tools more modular and adaptable. Instead of duplicating or editing an existing group, a closure can expose user-defined behavior while preserving the structur...

caption: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.
contextBefore: Captured values make it possible to preserve external parameters—such as scale, density, or color—without creating explicit input sockets. This makes closures cleaner and easier to reuse in different node trees.
contextAfter: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.

caption: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
contextBefore: When the generator evaluates the closure, the custom distribution defined in the zone is executed instead of the default behavior.
contextAfter: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
The Evaluate Closure node executes a connected Closure Zone . It acts as the call site of the closure, running its internal node graph and returning the resulting values.

caption: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .
contextBefore: Whenever the closure is evaluated, the connected node graph runs within the terrain generator’s context, producing a customized result.
contextAfter: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .

caption: Using a closure to customize tree scattering within a terrain generator.
contextBefore: Closures make node groups more flexible and reusable by letting users inject part of a node network into another. This allows building higher-level tools where specific parts of a process can be customized without modifying the group its...
contextAfter: Using a closure to customize tree scattering within a terrain generator.

caption: A terrain generator node group using closures for custom tree placement.
contextBefore: When the closure is evaluated, the contents of the connected node graph are executed inside the context of the terrain generator. This allows the generator to provide stable infrastructure (e.g., scattering, masks, attributes) while user...
contextAfter: A terrain generator node group using closures for custom tree placement.

The Fillet Curve rounds corners on curve control points, similar to the effect of the Bevel Modifier on a 2D mesh. However, a key difference is that the rounded portions created by the Fillet Curve node are always portions of a circle.

caption: The node can be used to round the corners of simple 3D poly splines.
contextBefore: Standard geometry input with a curve component.
contextAfter: The node can be used to round the corners of simple 3D poly splines.

caption: The node can be combined with the curve primitive nodes to make more interesting shapes.
contextBefore: The node can be used to round the corners of simple 3D poly splines.
contextAfter: The node can be combined with the curve primitive nodes to make more interesting shapes.

Generate new curves on points by interpolating between existing curves. This is useful to have a smaller set of original curves to make editing easier and faster while still generating high-density curves for the viewport or a final render.
The Resample Curve node creates a poly spline for each input spline. In the Count and Length modes, the control points of the new poly splines will have uniform spacing.
The Reverse Curve node swaps the start and end of splines. The shape of the splines is not changed.
The Subdivide Curve node adds more control points in between existing control points on the curve input. For Bézier and poly splines, the shape of the spline will not be changed at all.
The Trim Curve node shortens each spline in the curve by removing sections at the start and end of each spline.
The Arc node generates a poly spline arc. The node has two modes, Radius and Points.
The Bézier Segment node generates a 2D Bézier spline from the given control points and handles.
The Curve Circle node generates a poly spline circle.
The Curve Line node generates poly spline line.
The Spiral node generates a poly spline in a spiral shape. It can be used to create springs or other similar objects. By default the spiral twists in a clockwise fashion.
The Quadratic Bézier node generates a poly spline curve from the given control points. The generated shape is a parabola.
The Quadrilateral node generates a polygon with four points, with different modes.

The Star node generates a poly spline in a star pattern by connecting alternating points of two circles. The points on the inner circle are offset by a rotation so that they lie in between the points on the outer circle. This offset can...

The Curve Length node outputs the length of all splines added together.

The Curve Tangent node outputs the direction that a curve points in at each control point, depending on the direction of the curve (which can be controlled with the Reverse Curve Node ). The output values are normalized vectors.

The Curve Tilt node outputs the angle used to turn the curve normal around the direction of the curve tangent in its evaluated points. Keep in mind that the output is per control point, just like the values that can be controlled in curv...

The Spline Length node outputs the total length of each spline, as a distance, or a number of points. This is different than the Curve Length node, which adds up the total length for all of the curve’s splines.

contextAfter: The Material Index node outputs which material in the list of materials of the geometry each element corresponds to. Currently the node supports mesh data, where material_index is a built-in attribute on faces.

The Replace Material node swaps one material with another. Replacing a material with this node is more efficient than creating a selection of all faces with the old material with the Material Selection Node and then using the Set Materia...

The Set Material changes the material assignment in the specified selection, by adjusting the material_index attribute. If the material is already used on the geometry, the existing material index will be reused.

pageTitle: Set Material Index Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Material Index node sets the material index for a geometry.
The Bake node allows saving and loading intermediate geometries. This node bakes parts of the node tree for better performance.
The Bounding Box node creates a box mesh with the minimum volume that encapsulates the geometry of the input. The node also can output the vector positions of the bounding dimensions.

caption: Bounding Box node used to create a box that encapsulates the geometry of the monkey mesh.
contextBefore: The coordinates corresponding to the box’s +X, +Y, +Z position values, i.e. how far the box extends in each of the positive axes directions.
contextAfter: Bounding Box node used to create a box that encapsulates the geometry of the monkey mesh.
The Convex Hull node outputs a convex mesh that is enclosing all points in the input geometry.

The Delete Geometry node removes the selected part of a geometry. It behaves similarly to the Delete tool in Edit Mode. The type of elements to be deleted can be specified with the domain and mode properties.

The Displace Geometry node moves geometry elements along a specified direction or vector, offsetting their positions to create deformations or surface displacements. It can be used to apply procedural surface detail, simulate wave-like m...

The Duplicate Elements node creates a new geometry with the specified elements from the input duplicated an arbitrary number of times. The positions of elements are not changed, so all of the duplicates will be at the exact same location.

contextBefore: An attribute field with a value for every output element describing which duplicate of the corresponding input. The value for every input element will start at 0 and increase to Amount - 1 .
contextAfter: Combined with the Geometry to Instance Node , this can be used to create a basic efficient “Array” operation. This should be more efficient because the duplicates are instances .

pageTitle: Merge by Distance Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Merge by Distance node merges selected mesh vertices or point cloud points within a given distance, merging surrounding geometry where necessary. This operation is similar to the Merge by Distance operator or the Weld Modifier .

pageTitle: Merge by Distance Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Using the selection input to only merge some of the points in a point cloud.
contextBefore: Standard geometry output.
contextAfter: Using the selection input to only merge some of the points in a point cloud.
The Separate Components node splits a geometry into a separate output for each type of data in the geometry.
The Separate Geometry node produces two geometry outputs. Based on the Selection input, the input geometry is split between the two outputs.

The Smooth Geometry node smooths connected parts of a geometry by averaging the positions of neighboring elements. It can be used to reduce surface irregularities or create a softened, more organic appearance without significantly alteri...
The Sort Elements node rearranges geometry elements by changing their indices.

pageTitle: Split To Instances Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: Splits a selection of geometry elements (such as faces) into groups, then turns each group into an instance .

pageTitle: Split To Instances Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: Group ID of each instance.
contextAfter: In the example above, we start with a grid of 1000x1000 square faces serving as “pixels.” Then, we group these faces into patches by assigning them a group ID sampled from a Voronoi texture, and move each resulting instance by a random a...

The Transform Geometry Node allows you to move, rotate or scale the geometry. The transformation is applied to the entire geometry, and not per element. The Set Position Node is used for moving individual points of a geometry. For transf...
The Active Element node outputs the index of the Active point, edge, face, or layer.
The ID node gives an integer value indicating the stable random identifier of each element on the point domain, which is stored in the id attribute.

The Index node gives an integer value indicating the position of each element in the list, starting at zero. This depends on the internal order of the data in the geometry, which is not necessarily visible in the 3D Viewport. However, th...
The Named Attribute node outputs the data of an attribute based on the context of where it is connected (the Field Context ).

The Normal node returns a vector for each evaluated point indicating the normal direction . The output can depend on the attribute domain used in the node evaluating the field, but the output is always a normalized unit vector .
The Position node outputs a vector of each point of the geometry the node is connected to.

The Radius node outputs the radius value at each point on the evaluated geometry. For curves, this value is used for things like determining the size of the mesh created in the Curve to Mesh node. For point clouds, the value is used for...
The Selection node outputs true for geometry that is selected , and false elsewhere.
The Geometry Proximity node computes the closest location on the target geometry.

caption: The three target element modes: faces, edges, and points.
contextBefore: The different modes of the node: faces, edges and points. In this example the Geometry Nodes modifier is added on the target plane. Note that the larger plane is subdivided and the smaller plane is not.
contextAfter: The three target element modes: faces, edges, and points.

caption: Points distributed on a sphere used as a target for a distance used in a shader.
contextBefore: The three target element modes: faces, edges, and points.
contextAfter: Points distributed on a sphere used as a target for a distance used in a shader.
The Index of Nearest node is a way to find other close elements in the same geometry. If needed you can use Group ID to determine the group of neighbors to be analyzed together.

The Raycast node intersects rays from one geometry onto another. The source geometry is defined by the context of the node that the Raycast node is connected to. Each ray computes hit points on the target mesh and outputs normals, distan...
The Sample Index node retrieves values from a source geometry at a specific index.

caption: Here the node is used to copy the positions of one object to another. This recreates the behavior of the Transfer Attribute node from Blender versions before 3.4. This works best when their geometries have the same number of points and the same Topology .
contextBefore: The data retrieved from the source Geometry input.
contextAfter: Here the node is used to copy the positions of one object to another. This recreates the behavior of the Transfer Attribute node from Blender versions before 3.4. This works best when their geometries have the same number of points and t...
The Sample Nearest node retrieves the index of the geometry element in its input geometry that is closest to the input position.

caption: Combining this node with the Sample Index Node gives a setup that can retrieve the closest attribute value from another geometry. This is the same behavior as the Transfer Attribute node in versions of Blender before 3.4.
contextBefore: The index of the closest geometry element of the chosen domain. For the Face Corner domain this is defined to be the closest corner on the closest face.
contextAfter: Combining this node with the Sample Index Node gives a setup that can retrieve the closest attribute value from another geometry. This is the same behavior as the Transfer Attribute node in versions of Blender before 3.4.

The Box Selection node creates a selection of elements located within a defined 3D box. It can be used to isolate geometry inside a specific region of space, such as selecting points, faces, or instances within a bounded area.

The Normal Selection node creates a selection of elements whose normals point in a specified direction within a given angular threshold. It is useful for selecting geometry that faces a certain way, such as upward-facing surfaces, walls,...

The Sphere Selection node creates a selection of elements that lie within a defined spherical region. It can be used to isolate points, faces, or instances inside or near a sphere, making it useful for localized effects, falloffs, or reg...

pageTitle: Set Geometry Name Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Geometry Name node stores a custom name on the geometry, overriding the name which might come from the Object Info Node or a Grease Pencil to Curves Node . The name is displayed in the spreadsheet and can helpful for debugging pu...

The Set ID node fills the id attribute on the input geometry. If the attribute does not exist yet, it will be created with a default value of zero. The ID is also created by the Distribute Points on Faces , and it is used in the Random V...

The Set Position node controls the location of each point, the same way as controlling the position attribute. If the input geometry contains instances, this node will affect the location of the origin of each instance.
The Set Selection node controls which geometry is selected .

caption: Grid with gizmo in the 3D viewport.
contextAfter: Grid with gizmo in the 3D viewport.

caption: Example of a node group that has gizmos.
contextBefore: Node inputs that can be controlled with a gizmo have an additional icon. The gizmos of that node are shown if it is selected. Clicking on the icon pins the gizmo, so that it is shown even if the node is not selected. Modifying the gizmo...
contextAfter: Example of a node group that has gizmos.

caption: The gizmo is propagated from the Size X input socket to the Value node.
contextBefore: Gizmos are often automatically propagated when an input socket with a gizmo is linked. The gizmo then controls the value that it is propagated to, instead of the input of the node group directly. Not all nodes support propagating gizmos,...
contextAfter: The gizmo is propagated from the Size X input socket to the Value node.

caption: The simplest custom gizmo setup.
contextBefore: The most simple custom gizmo setup is shown below. The Linear Gizmo node adds a gizmo that is drawn in the 3D viewport. The gizmo controls the value that is plugged into it. When trying this, you will notice that the gizmo always jumps b...

caption: Simple gizmo setup where the gizmo position depends on the controlled value.
contextBefore: When the gizmo position is made dependent on the value, the gizmo works more than one would expect. It now also works in both directions: changing the value moves the gizmo and moving the gizmo changes the value.
contextAfter: Simple gizmo setup where the gizmo position depends on the controlled value.

caption: Example showing how to add simple gizmos to the built-in Grid node.
contextBefore: The Transform output of gizmo nodes should be joined into the geometry that the gizmo controls. This helps Blender to understand that the gizmos should be transformed together with the geometry later on.
contextAfter: Example showing how to add simple gizmos to the built-in Grid node.

pageTitle: Grease Pencil to Curves Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Grease Pencil to Curves node converts each Grease Pencil layer into an instance that contains curves.
Combines multiple Grease Pencil Layers into a single layer.

pageTitle: Named Layer Selection Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Named Layer Selection node outputs a Boolean field whose index value is true for Grease Pencil layers whose name matches a string input.

pageTitle: Set Grease Pencil Color Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Grease Pencil Color node sets the color and opacity attributes of strokes and fills on Grease Pencil geometry.

pageTitle: Set Grease Pencil Depth Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Grease Pencil Depth node sets the Grease Pencil depth order to use.

pageTitle: Set Grease Pencil Softness Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Grease Pencil Softness node sets a stroke’s softness, which controls how much a stroke’s edges fade out. Higher softness values create more transparent, blurred edges, while lower values produce crisper, more defined strokes.

pageTitle: Set Grease Pencil Softness Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
headingPath: Set Grease Pencil Softness Node / Example
caption: Softness of 0.0 (left) compared to softness of 0.16 (right).
contextBefore: The modified Grease Pencil geometry with updated softness values.
contextAfter: Softness of 0.0 (left) compared to softness of 0.16 (right).
The Boolean node provides a Boolean value.
The Collection input node outputs a single collection. It can be connected to other collection sockets to make using the same collection in multiple places more convenient.
The Color node outputs the color value chosen with the color picker widget.

caption: Color converted into a vector by interpreting RGB as XYZ values.
contextBefore: Color value indicated by the color picker widget.
contextAfter: Color converted into a vector by interpreting RGB as XYZ values.
The Integer node provides an integer value.
The Material input node outputs a single material. It can be connected to other material sockets to make using the same material name in multiple places more convenient.
The Object input node outputs a single object. It can be connected to other object sockets to make using the same object in multiple places more convenient.
The Rotation input creates a rotation from euler rotation values.
The String input node creates a single string. It can be connected to attribute name sockets to make using the same attribute name in multiple places more convenient.
The Value Node is a simple node to input numerical values to other nodes in the tree.

caption: Example of the Value node.
contextBefore: In the following example the Value Node is used to control multiple values at once, this makes the node a useful organizational tool.

contextAfter: The Vector input node creates a single vector.
The Dial Gizmo node is ideal for creating gizmos that control angles.

contextBefore: The Dial Gizmo node is ideal for creating gizmos that control angles.
contextAfter: Special gizmo value socket. Everything that linked into this socket will be modified when the gizmo is rotated.
The Linear Gizmo node provides the most widely applicable gizmo. It can e.g. be used to control the height of something.

contextBefore: The Linear Gizmo node provides the most widely applicable gizmo. It can e.g. be used to control the height of something.
contextAfter: Special gizmo value socket. Everything that linked into this socket will be modified when the gizmo is moved.
The Transform Gizmo node provides a compound gizmo that can control a position, rotation and scale.

contextBefore: The Transform Gizmo node provides a compound gizmo that can control a position, rotation and scale.
contextAfter: Special gizmo value socket. Everything that linked into this socket will be modified when the gizmo is modified.
The Import CSV node reads data from a CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file and generates a point cloud. Each row in the file becomes a point, with numeric columns imported as attributes.
The Import OBJ node loads geometry data from a .obj file and outputs it as instances.
The Import PLY node imports mesh data from a .ply (Polygon File Format or Stanford Triangle Format) file.
The Import STL node imports mesh geometry from a .stl (Stereolithography) file.

The Import Text node reads the contents of a plain text file and outputs it as a single string. This can be useful in motion graphics or data-driven workflows where external text needs to be processed or displayed.
The Import VDB node loads volumetric data from a .vdb file and outputs it as a Volume geometry. All grids present in the file are loaded and included in the resulting volume.
The 3D Cursor node outputs the position and orientation of the 3D cursor in the scene.
The Active Camera node outputs the scene’s current active camera.
The Camera Info node outputs the information about the selected camera object.
The Collection Info node gets information from collections. This can be useful to control parameters in the geometry node tree with an external collection.

The Image Info node gets information from image and animation. This can be useful to generate parameters in the geometry node for arbitrary images. Image information can be either general or frame-specific.
The Is Viewport node outputs true when geometry nodes are evaluated for the viewport. For the final render the node outputs false.

caption: Using Is Viewport to switch between low quality and high quality.
contextBefore: Boolean value that indicates whether geometry nodes are evaluated for preview.
contextAfter: Using Is Viewport to switch between low quality and high quality.
The Mouse Position node returns information about the mouse cursor such as its position and the region’s dimensions.

The Object Info node gets information from objects. This can be useful to control parameters in the geometry node tree with an external object, either directly by using its geometry, or via its transformation properties.
The Scene Time node outputs the current time in the scene’s animation in units of seconds or frames.
The Self Object node outputs the object that contains the geometry nodes modifier currently being executed. This can be used to retrieve the original transforms.
The Viewport Transform node retrieves the view direction and location of the 3D Viewport .

caption: Socket Inspection.
contextBefore: Generally, the inspection tools display data from the last time the node tree has been evaluated. If it has not been evaluated, no information is available.

caption: Attribute Search.
contextBefore: Socket values are only logged from when the node tree was executed, so a node must be connected to the Group Output to have a value for inspection. Values are not logged during rendering, to improve performance.

caption: Node Warning.
contextBefore: The Viewer node is used to display intermediate geometry in the Spreadsheet Editor and the Viewport. For more information see Viewer Node .

caption: The node timings overlay.
contextBefore: When the inputs to a node are invalid, it displays a warning in the title. Hovering over the warning icon shows the error message. These warnings are only generated when the node is executed, so a node must be connected to the Group Outp...

contextAfter: The Instance Bounds node outputs the axis-aligned bounding box of each instance in the input geometry. This can be used to determine the spatial extent of instances, for example, to position or scale objects based on their size.

pageTitle: Instance on Elements Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Instance on Elements node creates instances of an object, collection, or geometry on selected elements of an input geometry. It can be used to distribute instances on points, edges, faces, or face corners, providing flexibility for p...

pageTitle: Instance on Points Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Instance on Points node adds a reference to a geometry to each of the points present in the input geometry. Instances are a fast way to add the same geometry to a scene many times without duplicating the underlying data. The node wor...
The Instance Rotation outputs the XYZ Euler rotation of each top-level instance in the local space of the modifier object.
The Instance Scale outputs the size of top-level instances on each axis in the local space of the modifier object.
The Instance Transform outputs the Transformation Matrix of each top-level instance in the local space of the modifier object.

pageTitle: Instances to Points Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Instances to Points node generates points at the origins of top-level instances. Attributes on the instance domain are moved to the point cloud points.

The Randomize Transforms node applies random translation, rotation, and scale to instances. It is commonly used to create natural variation among duplicated objects, such as scattered rocks, trees, or other elements in a scene.

The Realize Instances node makes any instances (efficient duplicates of the same geometry) into real geometry data. This makes it possible to affect each instance individually, whereas without this node, the exact same changes are applie...
The Rotate Instances node rotates geometry instances in local or global space.
The Scale Instances node scales geometry instances in local or global space.

pageTitle: Set Instance Transform Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Instance Transform node Transforms geometry instances using a Transformation Matrix .
The Translate Instances node moves top-level geometry instances in local or global space.

caption: A node group that creates nested instancing by chaining Instance on Points nodes.
contextBefore: Since instances can store a geometry, and a geometry can contain instances, nested instancing is possible. In other words, it is possible to instance an instance, or even a collection of instances. For example, by default, the Instance o...
contextAfter: A node group that creates nested instancing by chaining Instance on Points nodes.

caption: The tree of instanced geometry for the example above.
contextBefore: Here, nested instancing is used to distribute geometry that contains both a mesh and instances. The output geometry contains a “real” mesh and a group of instances. Each instance contains a sphere mesh and many instances of a cone geometry.
contextAfter: The tree of instanced geometry for the example above.

caption: The properties of a Geometry Nodes modifier in the modifier stack.
contextBefore: Geometry Nodes is a system for modifying the geometry of an object with node-based operations. It can be accessed by adding a Geometry Nodes Modifier and setting up the nodes in the Geometry Node Editor .
contextAfter: The properties of a Geometry Nodes modifier in the modifier stack.

The Dual Mesh Node converts a mesh into its dual, i.e. faces are turned into vertices and vertices are turned into faces. This also means that attributes which were on the face domain are transferred to the point domain in the dual mesh.

contextBefore: The Dual Mesh Node combines nicely with triangulated meshes. In this case an Ico Sphere is used, which is made up of nice and evenly spaced triangles.

pageTitle: Edge Paths to Curves Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Edge Paths to Curves node output curves that follow paths across mesh edges.

pageTitle: Edge Paths to Selection Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Edge Paths to Selection node follows paths across mesh edges and outputs a selection of every visited edge.
The Extrude Mesh Node generates new edges or faces on the selected geometry elements and moves them by a certain offset.

contextBefore: A boolean field indicating the “side” elements in the extrusion. In Vertex mode, these are the new edges; in Edge mode, the new faces; and in Face mode, too, the newly generated faces (as opposed to the moved ones).
contextAfter: Here, the selection outputs are used to set materials on certain faces of the mesh. A Random Value Node is used to limit the extrusion to a random set of faces.

headingPath: Extrude Mesh Node / Attribute Propagation / Vertex Mode
caption: The new edges created in vertex mode use the average value of all connected edges.
contextBefore: The following sections describe:
contextAfter: The new edges created in vertex mode use the average value of all connected edges.

headingPath: Extrude Mesh Node / Attribute Propagation / Edge Mode
caption: Attribute propagation for new connecting edges (the vertical yellow edge). The final value is a mix of the values from the two middle blue edges. The darker maroon edges lower on the image are not used.
contextBefore: New edges have the average value of any connected original edges. For boolean attributes, edges are selected if any connected edges were selected.
contextAfter: Attribute propagation for new connecting edges (the vertical yellow edge). The final value is a mix of the values from the two middle blue edges. The darker maroon edges lower on the image are not used.

headingPath: Extrude Mesh Node / Attribute Propagation / Face Mode
caption: Attribute propagation for new connecting edges (the vertical yellow edge). The final value is a mix of the values from the two middle blue edges. The values from the darker maroon edges between unselected faces and on top of the extruded region are not used.
contextBefore: New face corners get the averaged value of corresponding corners in all faces connected to selected edges. For booleans, corners are selected if one of those corners are selected.
contextAfter: Attribute propagation for new connecting edges (the vertical yellow edge). The final value is a mix of the values from the two middle blue edges. The values from the darker maroon edges between unselected faces and on top of the extruded...

headingPath: Extrude Mesh Node / Attribute Propagation / Individual Face Mode
caption: Attribute propagation for new connecting edge. Each edge uses the average values of the two neighboring edges on its extruded face.
contextBefore: New face corners have copied values from the corresponding corners of extruded faces.
contextAfter: Attribute propagation for new connecting edge. Each edge uses the average values of the two neighboring edges on its extruded face.

The Flip Faces Node reverses the order of the vertices and edges of each selected face. The most common use of this node is to flip the normals of a face. Any face corner domain attributes of selected faces are also reversed.
The Mesh Boolean Node allows you to cut, subtract, and join the geometry of two inputs. This node offers the same operations as the Boolean modifier .

pageTitle: Mesh to Curve Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Mesh to Curve node converts a mesh into one or more curve splines.

pageTitle: Mesh to Density Grid Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Mesh to Density Grid node converts a mesh into a density grid , where each voxel stores a scalar value representing how far it lies inside or near the surface of the mesh. This can be used to generate fog volumes, soft-body represent...

pageTitle: Mesh to Points Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Mesh to Points node generates a point cloud from a mesh.

pageTitle: Mesh to SDF Grid Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Mesh to SDF Grid node converts a mesh into a Signed Distance Field (SDF) grid. Each voxel in the resulting grid stores the shortest distance to the surface of the mesh, with the sign indicating whether the voxel is inside or outside...

pageTitle: Mesh to Volume Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Mesh to Volume node creates a fog volumes based on the shape of a mesh. The volume is created with a grid of the name "density" .
Scales the selected faces or edges, letting you specify a scaling factor and pivot point for each one. Connected faces/edges are scaled together using their average factor and pivot point.

contextBefore: Standard geometry output.
contextAfter: The node is useful when combined with the Extrude Mesh Node , especially in Individual mode where connected faces aren’t extruded together.
Like the Edge Split Modifier , the Split Edges node splits and duplicates edges within a mesh, breaking ‘links’ between faces around those split edges.
The Subdivide Mesh node adds new faces to mesh geometry using a simple interpolation for deformation.
The Subdivision Surface node adds new faces to mesh geometry using a Catmull-Clark subdivision method.
The Triangulate node converts all faces in a mesh (quads and n-gons) to triangular faces. It functions the same as the Triangulate tool in Edit Mode.

caption: Mesh before triangulation.
contextBefore: Standard geometry output.

caption: Mesh after triangulation.
contextBefore: Mesh before triangulation.

contextAfter: Generates a cone mesh that is optionally truncated.
The Cube node generates a cuboid mesh with variable side lengths and subdivisions. The inside of the mesh is still hollow like a normal cube.
The Cylinder node generates a cylinder mesh. It is similar to the Cone node but always uses the same radius for the circles at the top and bottom.
The Grid node generates a planar mesh on the XY plane.
The Icosphere node generates a spherical mesh that consists of equally sized triangles.
The Mesh Circle node generates a circular ring of edges that is optionally filled with faces.
The Mesh Line node generates vertices in a line and connects them with edges.
The UV Sphere node generates a spherical mesh mostly out of quads except for triangles at the top and bottom.

The Edge Angle node calculates the angle in radians between two faces that meet at an edge. For the Face, Face Corner, and Point domains , the node uses simple domain interpolation to move values from the mesh’s edges.
The Edge Length node outputs the length of each edge in a mesh. It calculates the distance between the two vertices that define each edge.
The Edge Neighbors node outputs topology information relating to each edge of a mesh.

caption: Using the Face Count output to create a curve on a mesh’s boundary edges.
contextBefore: The number of faces that use the edge as one of their sides. When the value is one, the edge is a non-manifold boundary edge. Alternatively, when the value is zero, the edge is a loose edge, not used by any faces.
contextAfter: Using the Face Count output to create a curve on a mesh’s boundary edges.
The Edge Vertices node outputs the position and index of the two vertices of each of a mesh’s edges.

pageTitle: Edges to Face Groups Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Edges to Face Groups node group faces into regions surrounded by the selected boundary edges.
The Face Area node outputs the surface area of a mesh’s faces. The units are in Blender units no matter the unit system, equivalent to meters-squared at the default unit scale.

contextBefore: The surface area of each of the mesh’s faces.
contextAfter: Combined with the Attribute Statistic Node , this node can be used to calculate the total surface area of a mesh.

pageTitle: Face Corner Angle Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Face Corner Angle node outputs geometric information about the angle at each face corner of a mesh. It can be used to analyze the shape of polygons, detect sharp corners, or create procedural effects based on corner geometry.

pageTitle: Face Group Boundaries Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Face Group Boundaries Node finds the edges which lie on the boundaries of specified regions. These edges could be used to mark seams for UV unwrapping, for example.

pageTitle: Face Group Boundaries Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: Selection of the boundary edges of the different face sets. An edge is considered to be at the boundary if it lies on at least two faces with different identifiers.
contextAfter: Combined with the UV Unwrap Node , this node is used to turn the face sets (right cube) into a UV map for a texture (left cube).

pageTitle: Is Face Planar Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Face Planar node outputs whether every triangle of a quads or N-gons is on the same plane as all of the others, in other words, if they have the same normal .

pageTitle: Is Face Planar Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: Whether each mesh face is planar.
contextAfter: Combined with the Set Material Node , this node is used to visualize all non-planar faces in a mesh.
The Face Neighbors node outputs topology information relating to each face of a mesh.
The Face Set Node outputs which face set a face is in, and whether or not face sets exist in the mesh at all.

pageTitle: Is Edge Boundary Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Edge Boundary node outputs a boolean value indicating whether each edge lies on the boundary of a mesh. Boundary edges are edges connected to only one face, typically located at the open borders of a mesh.

pageTitle: Is Edge Loose Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Edge Loose node outputs a boolean value indicating whether each edge in a mesh is loose . A loose edge is not connected to any faces, meaning it exists independently of the mesh surface.

pageTitle: Is Edge Manifold Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Edge Manifold node outputs a boolean value indicating whether each edge in a mesh is manifold . A manifold edge is shared by exactly two faces and has consistent face normals, meaning it is part of a continuous surface without gap...

pageTitle: Is Edge Smooth Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Edge Smooth node outputs true for each edge of the mesh that is not marked as sharp. Otherwise, if the edge is marked as sharp, then the node outputs false.

pageTitle: Is Face Smooth Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is Face Smooth node outputs true for each face of the mesh if that face is marked to render smooth shaded. Otherwise, if the face is marked to render as flat shaded, then the node outputs false.

pageTitle: Is UV Split Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Is UV Split node outputs a selection indicating which edges in a mesh are UV splits . A UV split occurs when an edge connects two faces that use different UV coordinates along that edge, causing a discontinuity in the UV map.

The Mesh Island node outputs information about separate connected regions, or “islands” of a mesh. Whenever two vertices are connected together by an edge, they are considered as part of the same island, and will have the same Island Ind...

pageTitle: Shortest Edge Paths Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Shortest Edge Paths node finds paths along mesh edges to a selection of end vertices. The cost used to define “shortest” can be set to anything. By default there is a constant cost for every edge, but a typical input would be the len...

pageTitle: Shortest Edge Paths Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: Tip
contextAfter: The edge length is a natural input to the Edge Cost . It can be implemented with the Edge Vertices Node and the Vector Math Node set to the Distance operation.

pageTitle: Shortest Edge Paths Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Shortest Edge Paths on a deformed Ico Sphere.

contextAfter: Shortest Edge Paths on a deformed Ico Sphere.

pageTitle: Shortest Edge Paths Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Gradient-colored maze showing shortest paths to a target sphere.
contextBefore: Shortest Edge Paths on a deformed Ico Sphere.
contextAfter: Gradient-colored maze showing shortest paths to a target sphere.

pageTitle: Shortest Edge Paths Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Organic branching structure on Suzanne.

The Enable Output node toggles the visibility and value of a socket for a Node Group outputs. It can be used to conditionally show or hide outputs from a node group depending on an input value or condition.
The Viewer node allows viewing data from inside a geometry node group in both the Spreadsheet Editor and the 3D Viewport.

pageTitle: Distribute Points in Grid - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Distribute Points in Grid node generates points within the active region of a voxel grid. The number and placement of points can be controlled using the grid’s density values and various distribution parameters.

pageTitle: Distribute Points in Volume - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Distribute Points in Volume node creates points inside of volume grids. The node has two basic modes of operation: distributing points randomly, or in a regular grid. Both methods operate on all of the float grids in the volume.

The Points node generate a point cloud with positions and radii defined by fields .

pageTitle: Points to Curves Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Points to Curves node generates a Curves geometry by taking all points and inserting them to new curves. All Attributes from points are propagated to Curve Points . Built-in curves attributes stored in points will be ignored.

contextAfter: The Points to Vertices node generate a mesh vertex in the output geometry for each point cloud point in the input geometry.

pageTitle: Points to Volume Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Points to Volume node generates a fog volume sphere around every point in the input geometry. The new volume grid is named “density”.

pageTitle: White Noise Texture Node - Blender 5.0 Manual

The Combine Bundle node creates a new Bundle from multiple input values. Each input becomes an element of the bundle, identified by its socket name. Values can be accessed in other parts of the node tree using the Separate Bundle

caption: A cube and cylinder combined into a bundle, then separated again.
contextBefore: Bundles reduce the number of exposed inputs and outputs in a node group, and can contain mixed data types such as geometry, fields, values, objects, or even nested bundles.
contextAfter: A cube and cylinder combined into a bundle, then separated again.
The Join Bundle node combines multiple bundles into a single output bundle. Each connected input bundle is merged together, producing one bundle that contains all items from the inputs.
The Separate Bundle node extracts individual values from a Bundle . Each output corresponds to an element in the bundle, identified by its socket name.

caption: An empty closure zone.
contextBefore: Closures allow users to pass custom procedural logic into node groups, making tools more modular and adaptable. Instead of duplicating or editing an existing group, a closure can expose user-defined behavior while preserving the structur...

caption: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.
contextBefore: Captured values make it possible to preserve external parameters—such as scale, density, or color—without creating explicit input sockets. This makes closures cleaner and easier to reuse in different node trees.
contextAfter: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.

caption: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
contextBefore: When the generator evaluates the closure, the custom distribution defined in the zone is executed instead of the default behavior.
contextAfter: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
The Evaluate Closure node executes a connected Closure Zone . It acts as the call site of the closure, running its internal node graph and returning the resulting values.

caption: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .
contextBefore: Whenever the closure is evaluated, the connected node graph runs within the terrain generator’s context, producing a customized result.
contextAfter: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .

caption: Using a closure to customize tree scattering within a terrain generator.
contextBefore: Closures make node groups more flexible and reusable by letting users inject part of a node network into another. This allows building higher-level tools where specific parts of a process can be customized without modifying the group its...
contextAfter: Using a closure to customize tree scattering within a terrain generator.

caption: A terrain generator node group using closures for custom tree placement.
contextBefore: When the closure is evaluated, the contents of the connected node graph are executed inside the context of the terrain generator. This allows the generator to provide stable infrastructure (e.g., scattering, masks, attributes) while user...
contextAfter: A terrain generator node group using closures for custom tree placement.

caption: The For Each Element zone.
contextBefore: This zone type allows executing nodes for each element of a geometry. For example, the nodes can process every face of a mesh, or every instance.

contextAfter: The Index Switch node outputs one of its inputs based on an integer Index value. Only the selected input is evaluated, making this node useful for switching between multiple data inputs efficiently.
The Bit Math node performs bitwise operations on 32-bit integer values. It is useful for low-level data manipulation and logic operations.
The Boolean Math node performs a basic logical operation on its inputs.
The Clamp node clamps a value between a minimum and a maximum.

caption: Example of Clamp node.
contextBefore: The Voronoi Texture node outputs a value whose minimum is zero. We can use the Clamp node to clamp this value such that the minimum is 0.2.

contextAfter: The Compare node takes two inputs and does an operation to determine whether they are similar. The node can work on all generic data types, and has modes for vectors that contain more complex comparisons, which can help to reduce the num...

The Float Curve node maps an input float to a curve and outputs a float value.

pageTitle: Float To Integer Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Float To Integer node takes a single floating point number input and converts it to an integer with a choice of methods.
The Hash Value node takes a value input and hashes this to an integer.
The Integer Math node performs math operations.
The Map Range node remaps a value from a range to a target range.

caption: Example of Map Range node.
contextBefore: The Noise Texture node outputs a value in the range [0, 1]. We can use the Map Range node to remap this value into the range [-1, 1].

contextAfter: The Math Node performs math operations.

contextBefore: The Mix Node mixes values, colors and vectors inputs using a factor to control the amount of interpolation. The Color mode has additional blending modes.
contextAfter: Controls the amount of mixing between the A and B inputs.
The Combine Matrix node constructs a 4x4 matrix from its individual values.
The Combine Transform node combines a translation vector, a rotation vector, and a scale vector into a Transformation Matrix .
Returns the inverse of the given matrix.
The Matrix Determinant node computes the determinant of the passed in matrix.
The Multiply Matrices node performs a matrix multiplication on two input matrices.

Applies a projection matrix to a point. Specifically, this node turns the given Euclidean vector (X, Y, Z) into the homogeneous vector (X, Y, Z, 1), multiplies the given projection matrix by it, and turns the resulting homogeneous vector...
The Separate Matrix node splits a 4x4 matrix into its individual values.
The Separate Transform node separates a Transformation Matrix into a translation vector, a rotation vector, and a scale vector.
The Transform Direction node multiplies a Transformation Matrix by a vector.
The Transform Point node applies a Transformation Matrix to a position vector.
The Transpose Matrix node flips a matrix over its diagonal.
The Menu Switch node outputs one of its inputs based on a selected menu item. Only the active input is evaluated, allowing efficient switching between multiple options.

The Random Rotation node generates random rotation values within a specified angular range. It can be used to randomize the orientation of instances, particles, or elements of a geometry.
