The Invert Rotation node inverts a rotation.

contextBefore: The Mix Node mixes values, colors and vectors inputs using a factor to control the amount of interpolation. The Color mode has additional blending modes.
contextAfter: Controls the amount of mixing between the A and B inputs.

pageTitle: Quaternion to Rotation Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Quaternion to Rotation node converts a quaternion rotation to a standard rotation.
The Rotate Rotation node applies an additional rotation to a given one.
The Rotate Vector node rotates a vector by a given rotation value.

pageTitle: Rotation to Euler Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Rotation to Euler node converts a standard rotation socket value to an Euler rotation.

pageTitle: Rotation to Quaternion Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Rotation to Quaternion node converts a standard rotation value to a quaternion rotation .
The Switch node outputs one of two inputs depending on a condition. Only the input that is passed through the node is computed.

pageTitle: Find in String Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Find in String node finds the number of times a substring occurs in a string, and the position of the start of the first match.
The Format String node inserts values into a string using either a Python compatible string format syntax or Blender’s format specifier syntax.

alt: Format String node example with CSV data import.
contextBefore: Input names must be valid identifiers and must be unique. If a name is invalid, the format operation may fail or produce incorrect output.

contextAfter: The Join Strings node combines any number of input strings into the output string. The order of the result depends on the vertical ordering of the inputs in the multi-input socket.

The Match String node compares two string values and outputs a Boolean result based on the selected operation. It is useful for conditional logic involving string comparisons, such as matching object names or attribute values.
The Replace String node replaces a string segment with another.

caption: Using the node to add the newline character to a string.
contextBefore: Standard string output.
contextAfter: Using the node to add the newline character to a string.
The Slice String node extracts a string segment from a larger string.
The Special Characters node is used to output string characters that can’t be typed directly with the keyboard.
The String Length node outputs the number of characters in the input string.

pageTitle: String to Curves Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The String to Curves node converts a string to curve instances. Each unique character used in the string is converted to a curve once, and further uses of that character are instances of the same geometry. The name of each instance geome...

pageTitle: String to Curves Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: Outputs the position described by the Pivot Point drop-down in the local space of each instance.
contextAfter: The node can be used to make overflowing text boxes. Here, the text that does not fit into the first node’s fixed-size text box is passed to a separate String to Curves node, then scaled with a Scale to Fit node.

pageTitle: String to Value Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The String to Value node converts a text string into a numerical value. This is useful for parsing numbers from text input, file data, or dynamically generated strings.

pageTitle: Value to String Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Value to String node generates string representation of the input value.
The Combine Cylindrical node converts cylindrical coordinates (R, Φ, Z) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Cylindrical node.
The Combine Spherical node converts spherical coordinates (R, Φ, Θ) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Spherical node.
The Combine XYZ Node combines a vector from its individual components.

contextBefore: The Mix Node mixes values, colors and vectors inputs using a factor to control the amount of interpolation. The Color mode has additional blending modes.

contextAfter: The Separate Cylindrical node converts a vector from Cartesian coordinates (X, Y, Z) into cylindrical coordinates (R, Φ, Z) and outputs each component separately. It is the inverse of the Combine Cylindrical node.

The Separate Spherical node converts a vector from Cartesian coordinates (X, Y, Z) into spherical coordinates (R, Φ, Θ) and outputs each component separately. It is the inverse of the Combine Spherical node.
The Separate XYZ Node splits a vector into its individual components.
The Vector Curves node maps an input vector components to a curve.
The Vector Math node performs the selected math operation on the input vectors.
The Vector Rotate Node provides the ability to rotate a vector around a pivot point ( Center ).

pageTitle: Field to Grid Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Field to Grid node creates one or more new voxel grids by evaluating geometry fields on the topology of an existing grid. This allows generating new volumetric data (such as density, temperature, velocity, or distance fields) directl...

pageTitle: Grid to Mesh Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Grid to Mesh node converts a voxel grid into a polygonal mesh by extracting an isosurface at a specified threshold value. This process is similar to the Marching Cubes algorithm used in many volumetric modeling systems.
The Prune Grid node optimizes the storage of a voxel grid by collapsing uniform regions into coarser tiles or inner nodes, reducing memory usage and improving performance.

pageTitle: SDF Grid Boolean Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Boolean node performs boolean operations between two or more Signed Distance Field (SDF) grids. This allows combining, subtracting, or intersecting volumetric shapes directly in grid space, similar to mesh boolean operations...

The SDF Fillet node smooths or rounds off concave internal corners in a Signed Distance Field (SDF) grid. It modifies the field to produce softer transitions between surfaces that meet at sharp inward angles, similar to adding a fillet o...

pageTitle: SDF Grid Laplacian Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Laplacian node applies Laplacian flow smoothing to a Signed Distance Field (SDF) grid. This process gradually smooths the surface of the SDF by diffusing fine details and noise across neighboring voxels, resulting in a clean...

pageTitle: SDF Grid Mean Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Mean node applies mean (box) filter smoothing to amSigned Distance Field (SDF) grid. This operation averages voxel values within a local neighborhood to smooth out small variations and noise while preserving the overall shap...

pageTitle: SDF Grid Mean Curvature Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Mean Curvature node applies mean curvature flow smoothing to a Signed Distance Field (SDF) grid. This operation evolves the surface of the field over time based on its mean curvature, causing high-curvature (sharp or noisy)...

pageTitle: SDF Grid Median Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Median node applies a median filter to a Signed Distance Field (SDF) grid. This operation smooths the field by replacing each voxel value with the median of its neighboring values, effectively removing noise and small artifa...

pageTitle: SDF Grid Offset Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The SDF Grid Offset node offsets the surface of a Signed Distance Field (SDF) by a specified world-space distance. This operation effectively dilates (expands) or erodes (contracts) the surface while maintaining the correct signed distan...

pageTitle: Volume to Mesh Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Volume to Mesh node generates a mesh on the “surface” of a volume. The surface is defined by a threshold value. All voxels with a larger value than the threshold are considered to be inside.
The Voxelize Grid node converts all active tiles in a sparse voxel grid into fully populated voxel regions, removing sparseness.

The Volume Cube generates a volume by evaluating a density field on a 3D grid. The Density field can only depend on the Position Node . The grid points are equally spaced between the Min and Max bounds of the grid.

pageTitle: Get Named Grid Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Get Named Grid node retrieves a specific voxel grid from a volume geometry by its name. Each volume object can contain multiple grids (for example, density , color , temperature , or velocity ), and this node allows accessing one of...

The Grid Info node retrieves structural and metadata information about a voxel grid. It provides details such as the grid’s spatial transform and background value, which describe how the grid is positioned in space and what value is stor...
The Voxel Index node outputs the integer index of the voxel that the field is currently being evaluated on.

The Advect Grid node moves voxel values through a velocity field over time using numerical integration. This operation is called advection and is commonly used in fluid, smoke, and motion simulation systems to evolve quantities such as d...

The Grid Curl node computes the curl of a vector field stored in a voxel grid. Curl represents the local amount of rotational motion or circulation within a vector field—essentially, how much and in what direction the field “spins” aroun...

The Grid Divergence node computes the divergence of a vector field stored in a voxel grid. Divergence measures how much a field is “spreading out” or “converging” at each point, representing the net flow entering or leaving a voxel.

The Grid Gradient node calculates the gradient of a scalar voxel grid. The gradient is a vector field that describes both the direction and rate of the steepest increase in the grid’s values at each voxel.

The Grid Laplacian node computes the Laplacian of a scalar voxel grid. The Laplacian measures how a value at each voxel differs from the average of its neighbors—essentially, how much the field “curves” or deviates locally.

The Sample Grid node retrieves values from a voxel grid at given positions in space. It evaluates the grid’s stored data (such as float, integer, boolean, or vector values) and returns the interpolated result for each queried position.

pageTitle: Sample Grid Index Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Sample Grid Index node retrieves values directly from a voxel grid at specific voxel indices rather than at arbitrary spatial positions. Unlike the Sample Grid node, which interpolates between voxels in object space, this node reads...

pageTitle: Set Grid Background Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Grid Background node defines the background value for a voxel grid. This value is used when sampling regions of the grid that do not contain any explicitly stored voxels, such as inactive areas or tiles that have not been initial...

pageTitle: Set Grid Transform Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Set Grid Transform node defines the spatial transform of a voxel grid, converting its index space (voxel coordinates) into object space.

pageTitle: Store Named Grid Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextAfter: The Store Named Grid node stores a voxel grid inside a volume geometry under a specified name. This allows multiple grids (such as density , temperature , or velocity ) to be contained within a single volume object and accessed later usi...

caption: The Volume Displace modifier.
contextBefore: The Volume Displace modifier displaces existing volume grids based on a 3D texture. It uses the RGB color channels of the texture to displace the volume into the X, Y and Z direction.

caption: Fixed constraint options.
contextBefore: This constraint cause the two objects to move as one. Since the physics system does have a tiny bit of slop in it, the objects do not move as rigidly as they would if they were part of the same mesh.

caption: Generic Spring constraint options.
contextBefore: If the damping on the springs is set to 1, then the spring forces are prevented from realigning the anchor points, leading to strange behavior. If your springs are acting weird, check the damping.

caption: Hinge constraint options.
contextBefore: The Hinge is the only single-axis rotational constraint that uses the Z axis instead of the X axis. If something is wrong with your hinge, check your other constraints to see if this might be the problem.

caption: Motor constraint options.
contextBefore: The rotation axis is the X axis of the object hosting the constraint. This is in contrast with the Hinge which uses the Z axis. Since the Motor is vulnerable to confusing perturbations without a matching Hinge constraint, special care mu...

caption: Typical displacement node setup.
contextBefore: To create displacement, connect a Displacement or Vector Displacement node to the displacement input of the Material Output node. Procedural, painted or baked textures can then be connected to these nodes.

caption: Smoke and fire rendered with Principled Volume shader.
contextBefore: Principled Volume is a physically-based volume shader that can be used to create a wide range of volume materials. It supports scattering, absorption and emission in one easy to use node. Fire can be rendered with blackbody emission.
contextAfter: Smoke and fire rendered with Principled Volume shader.

caption: Volume Absorption, Scatter and Emission

The Ambient Occlusion node computes how much the hemisphere above the shading point is occluded. This can be used for procedural texturing, for example to add weathering effects to corners only.

contextBefore: Ambient occlusion factor without color tint.

The Camera Data node returns information about the shading point relative to the camera. This could be used for example to change the shading of objects further away from the camera, or make custom fog effects.

The Fresnel or Dielectric Fresnel node computes how much light is reflected off a layer, where the rest will be refracted through the layer. The resulting weight can be used for layering shaders with the Mix Shader node. It is dependent...
The Geometry node gives geometric information about the current shading point. All vector coordinates are in World Space . For volume shaders, only the position and incoming vector are available.

caption: Get a random value for each instance of the mesh when using an Array modifier.
contextBefore: A random value for each connected component (island) of the mesh. It is useful to add variations to meshes composed of separated units like tree leaves, wood planks, or curves of multiple splines.
contextAfter: Get a random value for each instance of the mesh when using an Array modifier.
The Curves Info node gives access to Hair information.
The Layer Weight node outputs a weight typically used for layering shaders with the Mix Shader node.

The Light Path node is used to find out for which kind of incoming ray the shader is being executed; particularly useful for non-physically-based tricks. More information about the meaning of each type is in the Light Paths documentation.

The Object Info node gives information about the object instance. This can be useful to give some variation to a single material assigned to multiple instances, either manually controlled through the object index, based on the object loc...

contextAfter: The Point Info node can be used in the material node tree for point cloud objects and gives access to the data of individual points. It can be useful to give some variation to a single material assigned a point cloud object.
The Color node outputs the color value chosen with the color picker widget.
The Tangent node generates a tangent direction for the Anisotropic BSDF.
The Texture Coordinate node outputs various coordinate systems that can be used for procedural textures, image textures, and other vector-based texture inputs.

The Wireframe node is used to retrieve the edges of an object as it appears to Cycles. As meshes are triangulated before being processed by Cycles, topology will always appear triangulated when viewed with the Wireframe node.

The Material Output node is used to output surface material information to a surface object.
The World Output node is used to output color information to the scene’s World .

The Principled BSDF that combines multiple layers into a single easy to use node. It can model a wide variety of materials.

contextBefore: The base layer is a mix between metal, diffuse, subsurface, and transmission components. Most materials will use one of these components, though it is possible to smoothly mix between them.
contextAfter: The metal component is opaque and only reflect lights. Diffuse is fully opaque, while subsurface also involves light scattering just below the surface. Both diffuse and subsurface sit below a specular layer. The transmission component in...

contextBefore: Overall color of the material used for diffuse, subsurface, metal and transmission.

caption: Roughness from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Specifies microfacet roughness of the surface for specular reflection and transmission. A value of 0.0 gives a perfectly sharp reflection, while 1.0 gives a diffuse reflection.

caption: Metallic from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Blends between a dielectric and metallic material model. At 0.0 the material consists of a diffuse or transmissive base layer, with a specular reflection layer on top. A value of 1.0 gives a fully specular reflection tinted with the base...

caption: IOR from 1.0 to 2.0
contextBefore: Index of refraction ( IOR ) for specular reflection and transmission. For most materials, the IOR is between 1.0 (vacuum and air) and 4.0 (germanium). The default value of 1.5 is a good approximation for glass.

caption: Alpha from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Controls the transparency of the surface, with 1.0 fully opaque. Usually linked to the Alpha output of an Image Texture node.

caption: Roughness from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Surface roughness; 0.0 gives standard Lambertian reflection, higher values activate the Oren-Nayar BSDF.

caption: Weight from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Blend between diffuse surface and subsurface scattering. Typically should be zero or one (either fully diffuse or subsurface).

caption: Radius from white to red
contextBefore: Average distance that light scatters below the surface. Higher radius gives a softer appearance, as light bleeds into shadows and through the object. The scattering distance is specified separately for the RGB channels, to render materia...

caption: Scale from 0 cm to 50 cm
contextBefore: Scale applied to the radius.

caption: IOR from 1.0 to 2.0
contextBefore: Index of refraction ( IOR ) used for rays that enter the subsurface component. This may be set to a different value than the global IOR to simulate different layers of skin.

caption: Anisotropy from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Directionality of volume scattering within the subsurface medium. Zero scatters uniformly in all directions, with higher values scattering more strongly forward. For example, skin has been measured to have an anisotropy of 0.8.

caption: IOR level from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: This input is designed for conveniently texturing the IOR and amount of specular reflection.

caption: Tint from white to orange
contextBefore: For metallic materials tints the edges to simulate complex IOR as found in materials such as gold or copper.

caption: Anisotropic from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Amount of anisotropy for specular reflection. Higher values give elongated highlights along the tangent direction; negative values give highlights shaped perpendicular to the tangent direction.

caption: Anisotropic rotation from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Compared to the Glossy BSDF node, the direction of highlight elongation is rotated by 90°. Add 0.25 to the value to correct.

caption: Weight from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Mix between fully opaque surface at zero and fully transmissive at one.

caption: Weight from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Controls the intensity of the coat layer, both the reflection and the tinting. Typically should be zero or one for physically-based materials, but may be textured to vary the amount of coating across the surface.

caption: Roughness from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Roughness of the coat layer.

caption: IOR from 1.0 to 2.0
contextBefore: Index of refraction ( IOR ) of the coat layer. Affects its reflectivity as well as the falloff of coat tinting.

caption: Tint from white to blue
contextBefore: Adds a colored tint to the coat layer by modeling absorption in the layer. Saturation increases at shallower angles, as the light travels farther through the medium, depending on the IOR.

caption: Weight from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Controls the intensity of the sheen layer.

caption: Roughness from 0.0 to 1.0
contextBefore: Roughness of the sheen reflection.

caption: Tint from white to green.
contextBefore: The color of the sheen reflection.

caption: Emission color variations
contextBefore: Color of light emission from the surface.

caption: Strength from 0.0 to 10.0
contextBefore: Strength of the emitted light. A value of 1.0 ensures that the object in the image has the exact same color as the Emission Color , i.e. make it ‘shadeless’.

The Principled Volume shader combines all volume shading components into a single easy to use node. Volumes like smoke and fire can be rendered with a single shader node, which includes scattering, absorption and blackbody emission.

pageTitle: White Noise Texture Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
contextBefore: The White Noise Texture node returns a random number based on an input Seed . The seed can be a number, a 2D vector, a 3D vector, or a 4D vector; depending on the Dimensions property. The output number ranges between zero and one.
contextAfter: The inputs are dynamic, they become available if needed depending on the node properties.

pageTitle: White Noise Texture Node - Blender 5.0 Manual
caption: Precision issue due to signed zeros on the Z axis.
contextBefore: Taking the absolute value of the seed. In computing, zero may be positive or negative, so taking the absolute values unifies the zero into a single value.
contextAfter: Precision issue due to signed zeros on the Z axis.

The Combine Bundle node creates a new Bundle from multiple input values. Each input becomes an element of the bundle, identified by its socket name. Values can be accessed in other parts of the node tree using the Separate Bundle
The Separate Bundle node extracts individual values from a Bundle . Each output corresponds to an element in the bundle, identified by its socket name.

caption: An empty closure zone.
contextBefore: Closures allow users to pass custom procedural logic into node groups, making tools more modular and adaptable. Instead of duplicating or editing an existing group, a closure can expose user-defined behavior while preserving the structur...

caption: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.
contextBefore: Captured values make it possible to preserve external parameters—such as scale, density, or color—without creating explicit input sockets. This makes closures cleaner and easier to reuse in different node trees.
contextAfter: Capturing an external input value inside a closure.

caption: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
contextBefore: When the generator evaluates the closure, the custom distribution defined in the zone is executed instead of the default behavior.
contextAfter: A Closure Zone defining a custom distribution pattern for tree scattering.
The Evaluate Closure node executes a connected Closure Zone . It acts as the call site of the closure, running its internal node graph and returning the resulting values.

caption: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .
contextBefore: Whenever the closure is evaluated, the connected node graph runs within the terrain generator’s context, producing a customized result.
contextAfter: Example: custom tree distribution using Evaluate Closure .
The Clamp node clamps a value between a minimum and a maximum.

caption: Example of Clamp node.
contextBefore: The Voronoi Texture node outputs a value whose minimum is zero. We can use the Clamp node to clamp this value such that the minimum is 0.2.

contextAfter: The Float Curve node maps an input float to a curve and outputs a float value.
The Map Range node remaps a value from a range to a target range.

caption: Example of Map Range node.
contextBefore: The Noise Texture node outputs a value in the range [0, 1]. We can use the Map Range node to remap this value into the range [-1, 1].

contextAfter: The Math Node performs math operations.

The Menu Switch node outputs one of its inputs based on a selected menu item. Only the active input is evaluated, allowing efficient switching between multiple options.

headingPath: Repeat Zone / Cycles and EEVEE Differences
caption: Error shown when Cycles is selected as the active Render Engine .
contextBefore: The number of iterations in Cycles must evaluate to a constant value. This means the number of iterations can’t be driven by Input Nodes or Texture Nodes .
contextAfter: Error shown when Cycles is selected as the active Render Engine .

contextBefore: Cycles Only
contextAfter: The Script Node allows you to load and use custom shaders written in Open Shading Language (OSL) within the Cycles renderer. This node acts as a bridge between OSL shader code and the node-based material system in Blender.
The Combine Cylindrical node converts cylindrical coordinates (R, Φ, Z) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Cylindrical node.
The Combine Spherical node converts spherical coordinates (R, Φ, Θ) into a Cartesian vector (X, Y, Z). It is the inverse of the Separate Spherical node.
The Combine XYZ Node combines a vector from its individual components.
The Vector Curves node maps an input vector components to a curve.

contextBefore: The Mapping node transforms the input vector by applying translation, rotation, and scaling.
contextAfter: The inputs of the node are dynamic. In particular, the Location input is only available in the Texture and Point vector types.

caption: Mapping node example.
contextBefore: The input vector after transformation.
The Mix Node mixes values, colors and vectors inputs using a factor to control the amount of interpolation. The Color mode has additional blending modes.
contextAfter: Controls the amount of mixing between the A and B inputs.
The Normal node generates a normal vector and a dot product.

contextAfter: The Separate Cylindrical node converts a vector from Cartesian coordinates (X, Y, Z) into cylindrical coordinates (R, Φ, Z) and outputs each component separately. It is the inverse of the Combine Cylindrical node.

The Separate Spherical node converts a vector from Cartesian coordinates (X, Y, Z) into spherical coordinates (R, Φ, Θ) and outputs each component separately. It is the inverse of the Combine Spherical node.
The Separate XYZ Node splits a vector into its individual components.
The Vector Transform node allows converting a vector, point, or normal between world and camera and object coordinate space.
The Vector Math node performs the selected math operation on the input vectors.
The Vector Rotate Node provides the ability to rotate a vector around a pivot point ( Center ).

caption: Collection properties.
contextBefore: Collection properties tab allows convenient access to properties for the active collection.

caption: Collections panel.
contextBefore: Object tab ‣ Collections

caption: The blend-file and its stored data.
contextBefore: In Blender, objects are not directly part of the scenes. Instead, they all get stored in a main database (basically the blend-file).
contextAfter: The blend-file and its stored data.

caption: The scene collection.
contextBefore: When they are stored in a scene, they are part of a so-called scene collection . So ultimately all the scene objects belong to this special collection.

caption: Venn diagram.
contextBefore: It works like a Venn diagram, where all the objects are part of the scene collection , but can also be part of multiple collections.

caption: Scene organization.
contextBefore: The result is a clear and flexible way to arrange objects together on the Scene level.

caption: Nested collections.
contextBefore: Collections can be named and sorted hierarchically. Just like folders can have subfolders in any operating system, collections can have nested collections too.

contextBefore: These brushes generally push vertices outwards and inwards and are the most customizable to achieve a wide variety of effects. They typically don’t use a color in their thumbnail.

contextBefore: Much sharper and stronger Crease brush. Great for creating thin and deep pinches.
contextAfter: Recognizable by their red thumbnail and cursor. These brushes generally flatten or heighten the contrast of the surface.

contextBefore: Scrapes the mesh with two angled planes at the same time, producing a sharp edge between them.
contextAfter: Recognizable by their yellow icon and cursor. These brushes generally move, pinch and magnify the mesh.

contextBefore: Transform specifically mesh boundaries with various deformations.
contextAfter: No clear color assignment. These brushes are general purpose brushes or specific.

contextBefore: Smear displacement information on a Multiresolution modifier.
contextAfter: Recognizable by their blue thumbnails. These brushes are used for painting color attributes within sculpt mode.

contextBefore: These brushes are similar to regular brushes but with an additional cloth simulation applied. These are ideally used on a relatively low resolution, since the mesh density defines the size of cloth dynamics.

caption: An example of various VDM brushes used on a smooth head from the official demo file.

contextAfter: An example of various VDM brushes used on a smooth head from the official demo file.

contextAfter: Preserves the object’s silhouette shape by only grabbing vertices on one side of the mesh curvature. The shape of the silhouette is determined by the orientation of the 3D Viewport and the start of the stroke.

contextBefore: If the Falloff Shape is set to Projected , the brush can grab infinitely deep into the viewport. This is especially useful for much broader changes to a sculpt.

headingPath: Expand / Expand Mask by Topology / Usage
caption: The typical result when using the Diagonals falloff to expand along the quads of the face.
contextBefore: By default the expansion will use a Geodesic falloff 1 to create perfectly accurate distances along the surfaces. Use other falloff types via 2 , 3 & 4 to expand via triangles, whole faces or scene distances instead.
contextAfter: The typical result when using the Diagonals falloff to expand along the quads of the face.

headingPath: Expand / Expand Mask by Topology / Usage
contextBefore: While using any Transform tool, the pivot point will automatically snap the border of an Expand result. This way areas (Like limbs) can be masked and then immediately rotated or otherwise transformed.
contextAfter: The different falloff types can be used for circular, triangular and square patterns. More loops can also be added/removed via W & Q to repeat the pattern across the mesh.

headingPath: Expand / Expand Mask by Topology / Usage
caption: An example of using expand with mirror options, loops and a recursion to create wood carving patterns.
contextBefore: The different falloff types can be used for circular, triangular and square patterns. More loops can also be added/removed via W & Q to repeat the pattern across the mesh.
contextAfter: An example of using expand with mirror options, loops and a recursion to create wood carving patterns.

headingPath: Expand / Expand Mask by Topology / Usage
caption: An example of using loops and gradients with multiple expanded masks.
contextBefore: A “Recursions” with R or Alt - R will start a new expansion along the border of the current expansion. Doing this multiple times, can help for increasingly random patterns or advanced pattern creation.
contextAfter: An example of using loops and gradients with multiple expanded masks.

contextBefore: This technique is especially useful to block out the initial shape of an object. It also has the advantage of removing any overlapping geometry and creating a manifold volume as a result.
contextAfter: Any currently used mask, face sets and color attributes will be re-projected on the remeshed result. Reaching high vertex counts should still be achievable with this technique, depending on the used hardware.

contextBefore: To more easily access this feature, use the shortcuts R to define the resolution, and Ctrl - R to execute the remeshing.
Dynamic topology (aka Dyntopo) is a dynamic tessellation sculpting method that automatically adds and removes topology under the brush.
contextAfter: Unlike the Voxel Remesher, this makes it possible to sculpt complex shapes without thinking about the resolution or topology. It also allows to define a different resolution wherever necessary. Much more complex base mesh sculpting is es...

contextBefore: Because Dyntopo and the Voxel Remesher are mutually exclusive and cannot be used at the same time, both use the same shortcut to define the remeshing resolution.
contextAfter: Brushes like Density , Snake Hook and Clay Strips work especially well with this feature.

contextBefore: The Multiresolution Modifier can be used for subdivision based sculpting. This means the object will be subdivided, similar to the Subdivision Surface Modifier , only that the subdivisions can be freely sculpted for very high resolution...
The inner ring of the brush cursor is used to visualize the strength of the brush.
There are many brushes to choose from but these are the most common brushes to be used during sculpting. More information on sculpting brushes in the Toolbar .
contextAfter: Block out broad shapes and build up volumes before refining them further.

contextBefore: Instead of sculpting cloth manually or creating complex physics simulation setups, there are various tools directly in sculpt mode that offer a simplified Cloth Physics Simulation .
contextAfter: This has various advantages but is especially useful for base mesh creation and larger clothing folds and draping. Detailing is possible, but the slower performance on high resolution meshes and simplified cloth physics might not lead to...

contextBefore: Filters are tools which provide an alternative way of sculpting, because they do not rely on a brush radius. Instead they will affect any vertices that are visible and not masked.
contextAfter: The strength is controlled by click & dragging from left to right. The position of the cursor can be used to only affect specific areas, if auto-masking is used.

contextBefore: This operator uses a process known as Quantization which takes the input weights and clamps each weight to a number of steps between (0 - 1), so there is no longer a smooth gradient between values.

caption: Levels example.
contextBefore: No weight will ever be set to values above 1.0 or below 0.0 regardless of the settings.
